Review Text: We visited Ambewela Farm during our honeymoon and honestly wish we had never come. What should have been a pleasant, scenic stop turned into a disturbing and upsetting experience that cast a shadow over what is meant to be a once-in-a-lifetime trip. The reality of this place bears no resemblance whatsoever to the advertising. Promotional images and online listings show cows grazing on lush green fields in open countryside, suggesting a humane, natural farm environment. In reality, the animals we saw were kept almost entirely in concrete buildings with concrete floors, with no access to grass, natural habitat, or direct sunlight. The conditions were visibly dirty and bleak. The rabbits were the most distressing - confined to tiny, overcrowded cages, with multiple rabbits forced into each small enclosure, unable to move freely or behave naturally. The goats were kept in cramped box-like pens, often with three or four goats squeezed into a space barely large enough for one, including mothers and young separated into very small additional pens while the young feed and grow. Nothing about this felt educational, ethical, or aligned with modern animal welfare standards. Instead, it felt like animals were being displayed purely for tourism, with comfort and welfare coming far from second. To experience this on our honeymoon was genuinely upsetting, and we left feeling saddened rather than enriched. Based on what we personally witnessed, the marketing imagery is misleading, and visitors who care about animals should be aware that what is shown online does not reflect the conditions on site. To top it off, we found it extremely hypocritical and ironic that during our visit we encountered a sign which read ‘obstructions and cruelty to animals is a punishable offence’. If this statement were true, this entire facility would have been shut down a long time ago. I would strongly not recommend this place to anyone expecting a humane, open, or natural farm environment.

we can enjoy by working in the farm and we can have fresh milk and milk product there. those are very tasty

Located about 15 to 20km away from the nuwaraeliya city worldsend road,. Ambewela is a dairies farm. Green pastures and other greenery is seen throughout the road. Quite clean.  There is a farm shop outlet if you want to buy fresh farm made products.visit if you have some time to spare.

This is a very big farm with a lot of cattle but the problem is that there are no staff who guides or shows around. You buy a ticket and go in and then there is no one who tells you about any process. You just walk around and comeback. Not as much fun unless you have a small kid who wants to see some cattle.
It's very we'll  maintain farm all the way it's nice green grace. There are some farm animals like cow, etc But mostly impres me is the nice green grace around the farm

A beautiful & well maintained farm, only problem is the road leading to the farm is muddy on rainy days. The area around the farm is so beautiful, some places resemble Europe. The Farm shop has stuff, the prices are the same as in any shop that has their products, so not worth buying stuff from there as You carry unnecessary load in the vehicle.
this place is look like very beautiful and all so we can get fresh milk. ambewala its very cool place. if you go to the go with the suitable dress.
We arrived here at around11:am and left around 3:30pm. Our kids enjoyed the chancidse to pet the cows and see how they are milked. We had fresh cow milk and fish rolls at the end of the day.
A must visit place when your in Nuwara Elita. No proper directions but you can get directions from the locals. Need to pay for the entrance.

For us, the view was very different and we enjoyed it so much, specially the way from Nuwara Eliya to this farm. Fresh milk, butter and cheese are available there. There is a minimum entrance fee, but I believe its worthwhile to go there, recommend this pl
Very educational.  A lot of walking .beautiful scenery of the farm. Well maintained farm. Fair stop over restaurant.

We enjoyed the ride to Ambewela farms . It was soothing to your eyes with all the lush green grass either side of the road. You get to see a series of wind turbines as well. The farm let’s it’s visitors to observe Breeding cows , pregnant cows , Goats , Rabbits and cheese making area. You can enjoy a nice glass fresh milk from the Newzeland restaurant. You can also purchase cheese from this location which are farm fresh . On our way we stopped near the lake dam where we enjoyed the view and also bought some strawberries from a local farmer .
This farm is a huge farm which is accessible to people. It charges around Rs. 100. But it is worth than the price paid.
😍😍😍 the view was just woww.. loved it..the weather was so romantic... the green fields 😍😍😍 its on the the way to hortain plains...do stop here..have fresh milk shake or nescafe coffee of fresh milk

This farm is the worst farm I had been to. Paid 20p as entrance fee and no guide nor clear instruction where to go. Sad and tired restaurant selling cheese and milk. Not much to see. Avoid at all cost!

Road to farm is nice and very scenic, saw all animals as mentioned in other reviews, saw cows grazing in fields as well. It was nice to watch cheese making process and were able to buy chili Gouda cheese for tasting, which was nice. On way back visited strawberry farm as well.

The road to Ambewala farm is flanked by extremely beautiful mountain sceneries with pastures stretching as far as the eye can see. Hills, mountains, lakes and tea fields can be seen. At the farm you can see the process of making milk and cheese and also how cattle are managed etc. Although there is nothing unique about the actual farm the road leading to it and the scenery makes it worth your while.

This is a farm consisting of cow, bulls, rabbits and goats. They have a huge area and have opened up a small part for visitors. The views are amazing and makes for good photo ops. they have a small cafe where you can buy milk and related items, unfortunately we could not try it due to the huge crowd.

Absolutely shocking conditions. The packages show beautiful fairy tale pictures but the actual conditions in which the animals are kept are appalling and unhygienic. The animal sleep in their own feces and are kept chained. The place is shockingly filthy because there is urine and feces everywhere even during the milking process during which the animals are hooked on to machines. The newborns are taken away and while the new born females are kept in tiny cages away from their mothers, a worker confirmed that the males were taken away and sold for meat. Even if one does not care about animal cruelty, the unhygienic conditions are enough to turn one off dairy forever.
This is a semi government owned farm operated by local farmers. You can see cow , goats , rabbits and bulls.  Very smelly inside but it didn't prevent me from feeding them grass  😊

Really enjoyed our visit here ,very nice to walk  around the farm with amazing views across the country.Very remote ,our driver had some trouble finding it, and the fresh milk shakes in the cafe  are to die for! Please in box me for general  advice on traveling SL , Bespoke tours offered , Island wide with local drivers speaking three languages (Tamil ,Sinalhese,English)
It was a good experience for the kids as they've enjoyed the trip to the farm really well. Very organised place and plenty of walking around. Here you could buy a pet rebbit

The climatic and economical conditions in Ambewela make it an ideal location for dairy farming. Ambewela Farms are made up of two farms, Ambewela Farm and New Zealand Farm. Blessed with the cool climes and pristine environment of the hill country, Ambewela Farm boasts superior breeds of cattle, modern technology and top-quality pastures where cattle graze freely. The result is an organisation of international standards in a local setting, producing the best quality milk and milk products

Seeing cows grazing freely with their calves on the cartons and advertisements, I was expecting to see the same at the farm. However, the fields looked quite empty with cows stashed in a barn with the young calves stashed separately in another, it was depressing to see the calves separated from their mothers. Even in the goat shed, adult goats were on one side jumping up and down in a limited space whilst the kids were stacked in tiny crate-like cages, three stashed in one crate which was about 3 ft in length and width. I was wondering if they were ever taken out to walk in the fields. Truly I was not expecting to see such a thing considering the fact that I believed that Sri Lankans are gentle and kind on animals. The view from the farm is truly beautiful, but the treatment of the animals gave all that away.

Ambewela is situated in the lush green hills of Nuwara eliya, ambewela farms are made up of two farms, ambewela farm and new Zealand farm blessed. with the cool climes and pristine environment of the hill city, we enjoyed lots.don't miss this place on your trip to sri lanka ,
Surrounding is absolutely fascinating.Misty most part of the day.Good as an educational visit.I have the feeling that we disturb these animals by visiting

You have to travel about 17kms from the main road to the farm known as New Zealand farm of Abewela. Very nice view on the way. But very little to see when you go there. If you are interested in seeing milking of cows reach the place between 1200hrs and 1400hrs. Staff is not supportive of the visitors though they charge money for entrance.

This is one of the places you should definitely visit while on srilanka.  Cold Place and so many greens with animals surrounding. Don't forget to bring sweaters. On the way to Visit this, there are few more places you must visit as well (Strawberry Garden, Lake nearby etc.). Remember to have Good quality camera with you
Had a great time with the animals. Many things to see. Recommend a morning visit. Can a bit hard to find.

When I step in to the farm cold breeze make me feel the farming is a nice job, after enter to the farm they just show us only demonstrations of farming. My personal believing is , this place should be more based on farming activities that visitors can enjoy and gain knowledge.

It depends how interested you are in milk and dairy products. If you are then you'll love seeing all the cows, calves and bulls. Mind the smell and flies though as it stinks! There was only a little cheese making video to see how cheese is made, it would've been nice to see some kind of demonstration. The best part of our trip was trying some of the yoghurt made with the milk from the farm, it tasted great!!
A great place for kids and family. Lots of beautiful greenery and fresh air. Amazing roads winding through the hills of Sri Lanka leading up to this place.

It was a very refreshing experience to visit the farm.  The landscape is extremely beautiful and we enjoyed a lot though the weather was slightly hot.  Be careful while handling with Cows as they get angry sometimes.

For those who have NEVER been to a dairy farm nor  seen cows or livestock this venue may  be a worthwhile visit. For those who have  best reconsider another option. A shame really ,personally  thought  that with structured master planning targeting the educational perspective,imagination , creating areas for designed landscaping and clever marketing (as an example to compare, the Jim Thompson farms in Thailand) this venue would have had better chance of being as a "must visit" choice as opposed to an option to consider when there is nothing else to do.
Went there with my two kids and they had a good time. The fee for entry Rs. 200 Per adult and children free of charge

This is a very relaxed attraction. Definitely recommend if you are with children (young or a little older). The beautiful lushes green acres are a beautiful sight and the children enjoy watching the cows and the goats graze. You can also view milking (at specific times). In terms of activity there isn't much but for the money you pay you get to relax, walk around and enjoy the greenery. It's something which could be fit in to a late afternoon or early morning trip if you are coupling it with other attractions in Nuwera Eliya. There is a small milk bar where you get fresh, hot milk. Nothing perfect that cold weather and a nice glass of hot milk. Recommend taking a stroller for the young ones and jacket/warm clothing. It can get a bit chilly in the evenings.
This place demonstrates how to feed cows by people and also feed people by cows. Highly attractive local and foreign tourists' attraction.

Set among the rolling hills of Nuwara Eliya, this has a superb location, which reminds one of New Zealand, from where the herds originated. The herds were also of top quality, and judging from the massive bulls, were of good breeding stock. The walk in the biting cold was invigorating, but we were very disappointed that there was no cheese factory to visit, despite the signpost. Buying the products was also nearly impossible - only the snack bar and restaurant sold the the cheeses, and since we visited on a holiday and the places were teeming with schoolkids, this was a battle. A separate outlet for selling the products, and a greater product variety could easily be arranged. If they don't want each and every visitor in their cheese factory, an entrance fee can be charged. Methinks the owners are only interested in the manufacturing aspect here. Marketing must be improved considerably. Why open your doors to visitors if you have not thought through the entire process??! You have an excellent product here. Market it better at its origins. I would give this facility only a 'good' review, despite its stunning location. The entrance fee is not cheap, so the owners could use some of this cash to substantially improve their offerings.
Must visit if you went to nuwara eliya I suggest you combine with a visit to worlds End or Horton plainsSnacks served sufficient for meal. Wholesome andClean

This wasnt rated very highly by trip advisor, but by reading the reviews I knew my family would like it. We really loved the experience. First the view to the place was awesome - the greenery, the grazing areas for cows, etc. Then we loved feeding the cows. There were great spots for taking picture perfect photos. Then we had fresh hot milk in the restaurant, which i really liked. It tasted real good, and surprisingly didnt feel very heavy after that. Overall great experience. Those who are cow lovers, must visit.

Ambewela farm is a private dairy producing different dairy products. This is situated in an beautiful location in the hills of Nuwara Eliya. The location is a 30 minutes drive from the Nuwara Eliya centre and for me it would be an ideal spot for en-route tours and for bunch of . Good for children where they could see the big cows closely and to see the cows are fed and milked. There is a restaurant and another dairy product selling spot. Overall it’s a good place to visit during your visit to Nuwara Eliya.

If you're staying two nights in Nuwara Eliya, don't forget to visit the Ambewela farm. This farm is located on the route to Horton plains. Beautiful view around the farm, the animals are well looked after and a treat by the works. The scenery around is awesome and we enjoyed very much.
Nice to see how different the area is from Nuwara Eliya. Is a beatyful landscape and a Nice farm. Low price entree: 200 rupee per person.
Very good educational spot for children and adults, bit far to go inside and walk a lot, but really enjoyable journey since the climate is amazing

This is a nicely maintained farm, where the animals are well cared for. The scenery is gorgeous, and the farm buildings clean (well as clean as you can keep a place where the resident animals keep pooping :D) If you are an animal lover like myself, it might seem cruel that there is a building that houses pregnant cows who are chained up. But, if you look closely, you'll see that the cows aren't that restricted from moving. These are a type of tie-stall where the caretakers are able to provide individualized attention and care for the expectant cows, and makes it easier for them to identify any inconsistencies in a cow’s daily activity. The rabbits are bred for meat which is rather cruel, but they are also being sold as pets. The goats are bred for milk and meat. Refreshments can be found in the restaurant along with a selection of dairy products. P.s: The toilets are not so clean

We visited the New Zealand Farm as apposed to the Ambewela Farm (both are owned by Ambewela Farms) partly because I am a New Zealander but mainly because the scenery, apart from the farm buildings, is a snapshot of New Zealand. The likeness is almost unbelievable. We spent an hour walking around the various attractions at the farm and each drank a glass of warm milk.

The cows that were kept in the various sheds seem to be in very sad conditions. The pregnant ones for example were all chained with almost no room for movement. Calves were sleeping on metal racks. Live rabbits (sold for meat) are kept in small individual cages where the floors of the cages are uncovered wire mesh. They are in really uncomfortable conditions.

This is a kind of usual farm one would see in western countries. How ever, this gives an idea of dairy farm industry to the sri lankan visitor. Apparently animals are free roaming and seem to be well cared of. Facilities for the visitors are satisfactory.

Visited the farm with relations and friends. Located in a lovely part of Nuwara Eliya with well maintained landscape and amenities. The animals looked in excellent shape and well cared for. Well worth a visit for a relaxing time.
All the animals are very cute especially the rabbits. The staff was friendly and the animals were looked after well. A great experience.
Located in the small city of Ambewela a must see place in Nuwara Eliga.Gives us the feeling as that we are in New Zeland:)

The landscape of the area is amazing, something really worth of seeing. It is such a shame that such a big company did not give any explanation at all on how the milk products are done or where the animals are from. Also the lavatories in the premises were totally dirty.  That place is where food products are made and to find toilets in such state was shocking.  Especially after paying tickets for the visit.  The restaurant area was extremely basic, again with no info on how the yoghurt, milk or cheese are made.

This place is OK but if you are an animal lover or so, you would not like the place much. True that it is maintained in a fairly decent manner but when you see the animals in the barns and all you might feel sad. It's not like they have a say in what happens. Apart from that you get to see cows, goats and rabbits here. Also you can see the cheese making process. There is a small restaurant where you can enjoy  a hot fresh cup of milk which is quite tasty. Also you can buy cheese from here. There are times in which they take milk from cows. I think one is in the morning and another in the evening. Check before you go, so you can see it. On weekends place can be really crowded but since it has such a large area, it is not much of a problem. The place itself and the road leading to the place from Nuwara eliya is quite breath-taking.

The Ambewela Farms are located about midway from Nuwara Eliya and the World's End jumping-off point.  The pastures and fields of the farm, with the colorful cattle happily grazing is a sight completely unexpected.  The scene could easily be mistaken for somewhere in New Zealand.  Gorgeous landscape!  Great place for visitors to gain some exposure to a modern working farm.  Also now a 12-turbine wind farm established on site.
Can see lot of animals there. Cows, goats, rabbits etc.. We also can feed them. Also have a live session of milking. Very nice weather with scenic atmosphere around.

We had a quick visit to the farm. It was well kept and a beautiful farm. Prepare to walk if you need to have a better look. Don't forget to taste their dairy product the yoghurt and chocolate milk. Check the weather, most of the times it rains or light shower here
One of the coolest and scenic places in Sri  Lanka to catch your breath. I never find it boring to visit there over and over again.

The drive to this place is simply amazing and so relaxing!! The kids enjoyed seeing the animals here and getting to pet them and also got to see how milk was collected and how cheese was made. Spent around an hour and half here and enjoyed the delicious fresh milk and curd.

An amazing view as we got close to the farm, the mist rolling over the green hills was truly picturesque. Cold... Misty and wet. Just what we city dwellers wanted. Fresh & flavorful cheese at the farm shop was a pleasant surprise.
Well, I am not an animal-lover but then again what made me like the place was the scenary which we pass on our way to the farm :) its all green plains with blue sky!

First the road towards the farm from Nuwara Eliya was amazing with grass rich fields on both side of the road provided a very pictorial view. The Farm itself is huge, it has a cattle shed which shows live cow milking, it has a goat shed also with little calves were so cute. A rabbit shed also which are generally used for Meat. Overall nice learning experience for Kids. Must go with the family
Sorry for the incorrect price of a fresh glass of hot milk. It was only Rs. 50 or $0.50 cents and not $7.00. It is worth a try. the best milk I have ever tasted.

This a very good farm, only cattle, imported from New Zealand. Very clean place, but visitors are not allowed in to the farm. The place sell, hot  Pure Cow's Milk, around A$7.00 a glass. The best I have ever tasted.
The place is amazing and you feel like heaven when you walk through the area. The cow milking is the highlight place and other places are very nice. You can have goat milk as well.
Just amazing. We were surprised how well this place is managed. It was very interesting even for us being adults. The animals are well looked after and a treat to see. The scenery around is awsome.

Do not miss a visit to this farm. The cow milking is the highlight. The entrance fee is extremely low, so make a stop here. U can also take the kids for a walk around and see goats and sheep. Well worth the visit

Ambewella milk farm is On the way to Hortons plains this dairy is the only one that has a tour of the factor and the cows. Its is worth a visit since it falls on the wa. really it is knowledgeable place

Lots to see and experience first hand. Be aware of the smell and muck! Uneven road surfaces when walking and not for the faint hearted. No disabled access and not suitable for elderly who cannot walk much
I din't like the farm much, but the way when you go towards farm is beautiful. The blue sky and green grass please your eyes.

I enjoyed this place so much more than my 3 year old daughter! I loved the simplicity of this place. It has different sheds for cows, calves, pregnant cows, rabbits etc. It has a milking unit, cheese factory and a restaurant where you get fresh milk. I really liked this place and it is a must for kids! The weather was so beautiful and the lush greenary and the view of cattle grazing on the farms and mountains was just spell-binding!!

Great farm. Cheese company, farm products and all activities. You have to take Rs.100 ticket to visit this place. Theres no any guides or any detailed information. And you can buy products from the farm cafeteria.
This is the place where milk production can be seen of Sri lankans.Fresh natural milk  without any harmful chemical. Cold climate make rememer you  the Europia country

Best to go early morning as they open, guess it's around 8.30-9am. Less crowded then. From Nuwara eliya town need to turn to the Nanu oya Rd and then turn left to the Ambewela Rd. Horton Plains also on the same route. On the way you will have picturesque views. One might think is it actually Sri Lanka or New Zealand. Wind turbines can be seen on the way and the Kanda ela reservoir. First u will reach Ambewela farm which has no entry, only a Farm fresh restaurant. Travel further about 7km, you will reach Ambewela-New Zealand farm. Tickets for a local adult Rs.100 and Foreigners Rs.200. Inside cows, stud bulls, goats, rabbits, cheese factory( only through glass can be seen a small part of the process). Milking times are 4.30am to 7am / 12noon -2.30pm / 5.30-8pm However we can see only the afternoon milking process that too through viewing glass. There are a lot of cow dung on the path avoid stepping on them. No guide to explain the process, even at the cheese factory. There's a farm fresh restaurant inside too at the end of the path. Overall good experience for the kids.

We arrived here at around 3:30pm and left around 5:30pm. Our boys 11&9 year old enjoyed the chance to pet the cows and see how they are milked. We had fresh cow milk and fish rolls at the end of the day.
A must visit for children. The experience will be remembered forever by children. Well planned and maintained by highly skilled workforcer
Quite a nice place to visit! The Stud Bull! OMG like a Minotaur from Greek mythology ... HUGE! The fresh milk and cheese available there is quite good !
On the way to Hortons plains this dairy is the only one that has a tour of the factor and the cows. Its is worth a visit since it falls on the way but not really otherwise

The owners of this property must live on another planet if they are satisfied with the appearance and condition of this farm. Serious upgrading and renovation is needed. The Cheese area is a con job and should be deleted ,the weeds around the public toilets and the condition of the toilets needs attention . If you are presenting this tourism product to the world then you have to spend your income on cleanliness and better presentation. I worked cattle for 17 years and I enjoyed looking at the dairy herd. You must upgrade this product ,get your staff motivated and get the culture right. The Minister for tourism in your country would have to be disappointed?

Green valley of Ambewela starts around 5km before the milking station where cows are kept.. was such a great place to be seeing cows and calves. They also breed rabbits also. Had fresh milk and bought cheese. Overall its a hidden gem don't miss it
If you want to see greenery all around you, with buffaloes and cows grazing in your sight and just relax watching the mother natures, this place is a must visit
The place offers scenic views, a great place photograph. Kids will enjoy the animal. If you are interested in farm it is a good place.

Good place to visit if you or your kids not seen milk farm to know bit more about cows, milking process. Also have a small shop to buy yogurt, etc. We visited the place on our return from Horton Plans National park.

The views you get on the Ambewela road is magnificent. The green grass all around the hills and plains with bushy trees to add to the beauty will make you stay there for hours. You can see the cowsof Ambewela farm grazing as brown white and black speckles far away.Very beautiful surroundings and refreshing atmosphere.

This is real scenic beauty with Grren Farms all around. This is actually a Farm for Dairy (Ambewela Dairy Farm) with Hudreads of Cows, Calfs. Farms are actually grazing fields for these cows. Temperature is low in September End with floating clouds on the chest of these Fields. Good place to visit once. You can enjoy Pure, fresh & hot milk & other dairy products at caffeteria.

Well, the place is normal. Nothing was interesting. You will see different halls/rooms for cows/goats/bulls. It could be a good place for kids as they will enjoy seeing animals. The way to this place is beautiful and there is some good spots for photos. We have stopped several times and we enjoyed the way.
A good farm to visit by locals. It's only the farm lots of cows and goats. Nice chill weather. On the way from Nuwara eliya you can see some wind power plants too.

If you have schooling kids, its a must see. For Adults its just walk to see some cows & studs. Nothing much to see. When the staffs milk the cow what i've noticed is they are not keen in following hygienic procedures.

To be totally honest, a total waste of time... If you've ever lived in Europe, Australia or NZ, there is not even the slightest thing special about this place. In fact, the way they treat their cows is very inhumane compared to the lush and abundant vegetation that surrounds the "cow feeding and milking enclosure". Milk is 'alright'. Surrounding scenery is beautiful but you could really see the same elsewhere throughout Nuwara Eliya.
Beautiful surrounding as well as the way..... It looks like you are in country side of Switzerland. Beautiful........

Guide was enthusiastic about this place but afraid it doesn't hold same appeal to British visitors that it obviously does to locals. On day of visit it was public holiday in Sri Lanka and place was packed with bus loads of locals fascinated by trip.
The location has stunning views, interesting educational tour for children. The place is closed sometimes, inquire before visiting.

What a time we had! Rolling green hills, chilly weather, good breed of cows, cheese making. If you like photography, you should not give it a miss! You can spend  2 to 3 hours there happily clicking away. Highly recommended

Have been here before and visited the place during my last visit to Nuwara Eliya on my way to Bdulla as a stop over. Spent good 3 hours just walking and seeing the operations of the farm itself. If one is really in to learning about cattle farming, then this is a must visit, as the farm consist of more details on cattle farming, with different section to identify different stages of cattle farming. Whilst cattle can be seen as the main attraction time spent there is fully worth it, if you could visit the goats and rabbit sections as well. The place has one restaurant, with one section being and open section and the other a closed one where the general stink of the farm is kept away. Depending on the individuals, it is up to you to select which section to be used to enjoy some refreshment. Washroom facilities were available, and to my dismay it was not maintained and not up to standards. Would appreciate it authorities can look in to this as resolve. I am sure with the ticket being bought at the entrance the other revenue you generate from the visitors from purchase of goods, you may be able to maintain a more decent washroom facilities than this. Beyond the farm, the drive to the farm is a very pleasant one with one driving through dense woods, open plains covered in grass, which is a great wive, and for someone who is interested in taking landscape photography, i am sure this would a heaven. For those interested in wildlife, if you do drive slow and be attentive, you may catch the glimpse of bear face monkeys, oriental white eye, scaly breasted munia and a small quireel that is the colour of dark chocolate with no stripes to name a few.
You will fell that you are in the plains of Newzealand. Attractive windmills and cows. you can purchase fresh dairy products.
first time I sow how is working the farm. how they are collecting milk from cows. not only cows there have Rabbits,goats also.
This place and the farm land reminded me my journey from Edinburgh to Inverness. Scenic beauty and the cows are a must see for visitors

Surrounded by lush green fields. Very much similar to newzealand cow farms. Maintains well. Entrance ticket price is comparatively higher. Variety of milk products available at cafeteria, but not cheap as you expecting. price is similar as super market price. Near the highland farm, which is a well renowned dairy brand in the island. worth visiting this place if you are visiting nuwaraeliya.

It is farm with cows in 'like new zealand' landscape. Location is about 3 km from Ambewela train station. Cheap milk, yoghurt. Bizzare and recomended. LOCATION MENTIONED IN TRIPADVISOR MAP IS NOT CORRECT. Farm is not in Nuwara Eliya city!
The entire area is surrounded by flowering plants. You can watch the cows grazing before you get to the actual spot. One thing i did not like was the smell. All of the stable smell awful.

This was the best place i visited during my visit to Srilanka. There are 2 Ambewala Farms in the area. The one that is open to visitors is popularly known as New Zealand Farm. It has a LKR-200 entry ticket. You can tour around the farm unguided. They have some good breed cows/bulls and goats. There are huge grazing lands which adds to the scenery of the area. There is a milk shop inside the farm that offers very low priced fresh milk, juices, yoghurt etc. Fresh milk should be tried!!!
It is a well kept farm with very nice and attractive environment. Well maintained flowered paths and lovely atmosphere. Also, the way how they keep animals for meat and milk is a must to see....

We enjoyed walking around the farm and see the cows, pregnant, babies & more. Unfortunately we cannot see the process for making milk. Also it would be great if they provide a guide or translate the words to English. I also do not like how they keep some cows in small cages.
I do love the green mountains and the view more than the farm experience. to be honest i feel very sad about the rabbits who's living in a small cage for their entire life :(

Really a good place to get some good knowledge on Farming. Ambewela Farms have 2 farms The main farm and New Zealand Farm. Only New Zealand farm is allowed for public visits. It's recommended for travellers toward World's End. The Entry fee is LKR 100.00 for locals. There is a small cafeteria with decent price along with fresh cow milk. Worth a visit if you have Kids. Parking available. But the place is so smelly.
It a nice place. to see  cows, pregnant cows, calves and stinky rabbits.  Situated approx 17km from Nuwara Eliya town.  You must taste a vanilla milkshake.

the toilets are horrible you would think the cows have used it. no fresh produce on sale. conditions for animals especially cows are appalling with small spaces. needs to study aussie nz concepts to make it better
Grazing fat and health cattle is a nice scenery. Cool atmosphere is so pleasing and wash away the weariness.
Nice Place. but do not expect too much as it not that worth wasting time. we went as nobody guided as to how is the farm

Situated in the nuwara eliya district it's only 17km from the district capital nuwara eliya.its on the way to world's end on a well carpeted narrow road.even if you don't want to visit the factory,just go for a long drive.we went in the evening and it was so  peaceful and just beautiful.there is a small  lake too.
Popular farm in Sri Lanka located in a cool atmosphere. Must visit place on your way to Horton plains.

This place is very popular with locals, we were the only white people there. Tickets for foreigners are 200 LKR per person. Being adventurous we ordered full fat vanilla milkshake, bread and 250g of what they claim to be gouda cheese. Don't.

We went to Ambewela Farms and paid around 200 LKR as the entrance fees. its hectare and hectares of property and has an electric fencing all around. They have different sheds for Cows/bulls/calves and a milking station. The cows are milked 3 times a day. We visited their restaurant and bought Gouda cheese loaf and had vanilla milkshake. All in all a Fresh produce.

I have no idea why this place is so highly rated. First it takes forever to find this place and driving through maze of roads. Second the place is absolutely over crowded with school children. This is just a farm where you get to see huge cows. That is all! Do not waste your time and money on this place. Its cold outside and vehicles cant drive into the place so expect a very long walk in cold. If you are so desperate to see cows take a jacket with you and one more thing the place stinks of cow piss and turd. Avoid at all cost!

I loved visiting the farm!!! Our 7month old daughter who was otherwise grumpy all along loved it too! Saw baby cows, studs, had fresh warm milk from their cafe! Everything about this place is beautiful
We went to ambevalla on the way of Horton plains. There are lot to see in  farm.  Different varieties of cows their breeding site,Milk processing ect.

I thought I was in some temperate chill location when we stepped out of the vehicle. There is a lovely store at the farm when you can buy cheese and other dairy products; and best of all fresh full cream milk drinks and milk shakes. It is a good comfort stop from Horton Plains.

A little disappointed with this dairy farm which is popular with the locals. Not a lot to see and there is an entrance fee which is becoming a little annoying in Sri Lanka. Smelly barns where they keep the cows, Bulls and calfs. Basic cafe where they sell their produce. On a positive note, the surrounding countryside is beautiful and reminds one of New Zealand or Australia
This is one of the best places to visit if you are closer to NuwaraEliya. About 14 to 15 Km's from NuwaraEliya town and you can visit this place while you travel to Horton Plains as it's on the way.
Plenty of cows, grasslands and place to be amidst nature. The cows are majestic and children could pet them too

A beautiful cattle farm, to be more specific a milk farm. Situated in the hilly region of Nuwaraeliya, spread almost across 1000 acres, Ambewela farms is a must visit for people of all ages. Almost 2lac Cows from Netherlands are bred in a natural environment. The grasslands are lush green and picturesque. One can also have a look at the milking of the cows if lucky to reach at the particular time. We reached at 12:30pm and were fortunate to have a peep at it. There are different sheds where one can even have a look at the humongous Bulls, just born calves, grown up calves, expecting mother cows. Also the farm breeds Netherland goats and super huge rabbits. The baby calves are too cute. The amazing part about the entire farm is, the way everything is very well maintained and kept clean at all times. Also they have the cheese manufacturing unit and a cafeteria where one can have all kind of milk products. Their drinking yoghurt is worth trying. Photography is not allowed once you enter the main farm, but you can photograph the huge number of lazing around cows in the lush Greenlands while on your way. If you are traveling towards Nuwaraeliya then this is a must visit. Entrance ticket is not expensive at all for foreigners as well. Hardly 200 SL rupees p.p.

There are 2 farms in Ambewela, one call as ambewela farm while other as New Zealand farm. New Zealand farm is the one you can go inside and visit. Place is open from 8.30 to 5.30 as per the gate and they got ample parking. There are many cows and cattle to see and you can learn the process of cow milking from the staff, if you go and ask. There are some goats and rabbits too in the farm. You can see the milking from cows from 12 to 2 pm. Its very nice experience specially when you have little once with lot of querying about farms.

It is not at all great. Can be given a miss except unless you have small children who might be interested in looking at the animals. Infact they hardly show any cheese manufacturing. There is quite a bit of walking also, so not recommended for old people.
I had visited this place in the morning when the climate was at its best, cool and drizzling. There were hundreds of cows grazing all over the place and was a spectacular view.
Worth a visit if not been before.  Nice to see animals in breeding, milking conditions.  Also certain grades of cheese is available.
A better environment with cool wind. One of the most dairy production farms in Sri Lanka. A commercial spot became a tourist spot because of the natural beauty.

I am surprised at how this place got high ratings as it was the MOST uninteresting trip of our vacation!! The fee charged for foreigners is as usual higher than the locals (300 SLR if I remember right), but for this fee, there is no guide, no instructions, no signboards and no information about what goes on and what processes are followed on the farm. So we just walked around and saw a few sheds of pregnant cows, stud bulls and calves and a rather depressing shed containing rabbits in cramped cages. There are no sheds of goats or pigs. The cheese making unit wasn't functional. There is a small shop that serves products made there but you can get the same products at any regular grocery store in town. We witnessed the milking session which happens at various times of the day, but again, nothing spectacular - machines attached to the cows' udders to pump out the milk into large containers. The only beautiful part was the drive to Ambewala, and we got to see several cows grazing on vast green lands. This was pretty, but hardly worth the 3000 Sri Lankan rupees it cost to hire a vehicle to drive all the way there. Please skip this, unless, like I said, you just want to see cows!
Good for kids. Will have to walk a bit. It is a nice journey to the farm as along the way you can have some vivid views. Not very sure about safety measures for visitors.

This farm is situated surrounding beautiful landscapes. We saw cows, goats and rabbits in the farm. and it was a different experience. the climate was cool in the morning but at noon it was really hot. There is a cafe and restaurant where the visitors can buy diary products which are freshly produced in the farms.

The farm in Ambewala is beautifully laid out and very much worth a visit.  We travelled by train from Ella to Ambewala and it took around 2 hours of scenic beauty.  If you have never been to a farm, this is a nice place to see amazing green fields and some uncommon cows, goats and rabbits.  The restaurant offered some basic food and fresh milk along with other dairy products.  The cashier was cheerful and helpful.  It was a pity that there were no meats for sale since they had all been sold out! The other disappointment was that there was so much of litter throughout the farm even though there were many bins around.  Why do we Sri Lankans like to litter?  Let's keep our country clean please...

The place is located at  beautiful and scenic view area. We managed to see the cows goats and rabbits  farms inside the compound. the staff there were friendly and nice. its more or less like  a  mini New Zealand at Sri Lanka. For those who love the nature and fresh air this is the place to be at while you are at Nuwara Eliya.

A proper method should be introduced to discipline the lines at the ticket counter. It's chaotic. If the farm is open to public visits, it should be nicely maintained with guided tours in order to make the visit more educational and meaningful. This can be converted into a wonderful learning opportunity for everyone by involving the right professionals to introduce 'Method'. As it is, hate to say, but it's a sheer waste of time and money!!!

If you're going to go around Nuwara Eliya,don't miss this place. Needs a private vehicle to reach there. Spectacular views on the way to there. You have to buy a ticket to enter the premises. Not much expensive. Try some foods and drinks made with the milk of the farm's animals. You can see the cow milk collecting process in here. So cold here. Bring a sweater if you're unable to bear the coool.
Frist time I have visited and I got impressed the way thing are done and the way they keep the farm clean.
This was an experience for the two children as it was the first time they visited a farm. The farm was clean and the people friendly. He children enjoyed their visit here.

We visited in late evening, But it worth money spent for tickets. I saw false information for ticket pricing in reviews. The cost for local is rs 100 and 200 for foreigners which is a fair amount. This place is amazing to take nice photos in a clear day. I felt like i'm not in sri lanka.
beautiful landscape,all photogenic,u will see windmills,drink different types of fresh milk and flavoured curd,a good place.

Visited this farm with my local friends upon their suggestion. I have never been to milk farm in my country therefore it was very nice to see one. We also loved the farm shop where the different diary products can be found. We were starving to something European and were happy to buy some gouda cheese made in Sri Lanka :) It was tasty and good quality.

The New Zealand farm is located near the Horton Plains. They have a lot of Dutch Cows which they use for milk production. For a small price you can visit the farm and see the cows, the milking process and even a cheese factory. Besides the cows they also have rabbits and goats. We felt sorry for the rabbits, they were in small cages without any hay on the floor. But besides that part of animal welfare it is nice to see the cows and how the factory works. There are two restaurants were you can buy fresh milk and other products made of milk like cheese, butter and yoghurt. Except for the poor conditions in which the rabbits live, this is an interesting place to visit.
the approach to the farms is very scenic, miles and miles of green fields on either side. unfortunately when we went the factory was  closed.

It was a very nice visit for my 2 kids (after many years in Europe) and very instructive one.. The sights are simply great.. and very relaxing; one feels himself not only traveling on Earth but also in Paradise; It was very nice to show my kids the Goats and their various ages, the Cows and the milk extractions, also the very little cows sitting near their mothers; we also saw the rabbits as well as the Bulls..

Visited during the long weekend and it was nice to see that we have world class facilities of this kind in SL and the high standards that they maintain. Was lovely to see baby calves and to see how they process. Lovely experience.
My two young children loved the trip to the farm where they saw cows, goats, rabbits in beautiful countryside surroundings.

It was a lovely journey.  We went there by a van with our family members. There is a lovely view of the mountains.  The Milking Parlour has given times of milking which the tourists can watch it. There is a cafeteria which you can have a hot glass of fresh milk and snacks.

You are in the midst of friendly set of farm hands.Do not forget to visit the factory that makes ice cream and yogurt and the wind power stations.It makes you proud of what distance Sri Lankans have travelled in setting up farms to international specifications. To me it better than the farms of New zealand and Denmark.i have seen better green only in Ireland.Visit either ambewela or New zealand farms under one management and enjoy the beauty of the highlands

The most I loved is the nature, surroundings and beauties of this area, more than the farm, which is of course a good one. Spending time around, breathe natural air, the breeze, the greenery, landscape around this are is just amazing. A most to visit place.
We saw every corner of the milk processing at the farm and the herds of cows been milking, really awesome experience to gain once tripping in nuwaraeliya.
The milk products for sale are really good. The curd which is a yoghurt is outstanding. Lots of really good cows and well maintained. Great place
I visited the farm in January 2016 for the second time. The Farm was clean and nicely maintained. Worth visiting.
You can see various types of Foreign Dairy cattles, Goats, Rabbits. You can see automatic milking. You can feed animals. You can taste Fresh Milk products.

Visited on a very dull grey day but that did not spoil the outing.  Lovely to see the animals out in the fields.  Lots to see with milking, baby calves, goats, rabbits.   The have an "interesting" café where we sampled hot milk, yogart and various fried snacks. Take an umbrella and a jacket just in case
really good place to visit but when the weather is not good the whole trip gets spoild. it is good for the children too.
Nice place. Good fresh milk. i was visit with my family. and also nice location. kids are like very much. But Cheese factory was close.
Paid 2000 per person to get in to find that the Cheese factory was closed, restaurant and shop also closed so basically just got to see some cows in a shed. Don't bother

Good place to visit.but sometimes the weather is not good.the milk is really fresh and hot.hot chocolate is not available.but cool milk shake is available in all three flavours, strawberry,chocolate and vanila.i hope you guys will visit there.
Visited with my family Good place but Weaste of time. Soo sting and poor animal but good for children education purpose

If you can walk to place from Ambewela station (3 km) it is really nice view. You can see goats, cows, rabbits but most of them are caged. The places with animals are stinky and very unclean. You can see milk extraction(like 4 am-7am, 12 pm-2pm) but sometime it may be really crowded. The glass of fresh milk from the restaurant is really tasty.In our visit we couldn't see the cheese production as it was closed for lunch.
It's very special industry in Sri lanka You will get learn when you visit here about Milk production and cow farming. I've visited many time. Highly recomonding to school students.
Its the cleanest and nicest farm I've ever seen. They deserve a medal. It's fan-damn-tastic. Hope to visit again

its nice expeerians with kids. specialy are you living in sri lanka with familly dont miss this farm.more important for kids. another special thing is around sceneris look like NEW ZEELAND mountan graas lands with milk cows.
Nice views all round. Visitors just buy the tickets for observing things. No arrangements to obtain further information other than by looking

The lush green grass and surrounding hillside is similar to NZ. A visit to this farm would be interesting for anyone who has never visited a dairy farm before. It was disappointing to see animals caged. As we have relatives with a large dairy farm in NZ we were not overwhelmed by this place. Foreigners are charged $20 entrance fee while Sri Lankans pay $10, which is a far more reasonable price for what you get.

The place like paradise. every yard is green colour. beautiful view. you can see cows and how they make milks. also you should buy hot milk and drink it. it was very Delicious. the cost per cup is 75 LKR.

This is an attractive place according to my opinion. You have to go 17 kms away from the city,nuwara eliya. Can have a nice drive on hills. There are cows, goats, rabbits etc. Every where green. so cool!!! When going it's better to take umbrellas, hats whether it is a rainy or sunny day.Sanitary facilities are also clean. So I think that this is a must place to visit in nuwara eliya, if you are having a free time (even a half a day).

The Farm and the Milk Powder factory are beautiful attractions as well as carrying a big education value. They educate the visitors with all relevant information regarding the field of dairy production with illustrations and sketches.
One of the fantastic place i have ever visited!! you will actually feel like you are in New Zealand. everywhere greenery & mist air WOW !!!

I would suggest to go to Ambewela farm only if you have a half a day free and you don't have any better plans :) and only to enjoy the trip, walk, sceneries. You can catch a bus from Nuwara Eliya to Ambewela. But we preferred this route: 1. Bus N.E. to Nanuoya 15min-22LKR 2. Train Nanuoya to Ambewela 20min-15LKR (Ella train) (You can enjoy stunning views over farms, tea plantations, Horton Plain and waterfalls) 3. Walk from Ambewela train station to Ambewela Farm 30min-free :) (You won't miss the farm sign. The road is really well maintained, views are gorgeous, generally a pleasant walk) 4. Farm admission fee is 200LKR for adults, kids -1/2price Inside there are cows, baby cows, goats, rabbits and a small cheese factory. To be honest, nothing expressive. Sheds are very smelly, animals are a bit dirty, no information about the farm history or how the cheese factory operates. Restaurant didn't have any proper meals (it was a big disappointment for us as we planned to have our lunch there). Should mention that the actual farm area is well looked after. Well, at this point you have to turn back and take the same road to the train station. 5. You can come back by the same train+bus or take a direct bus to N.E. ** before you start your trip check the train and bus schedule :)

You can see some animals such as rabbits, cows, goats and etc. Kids can see feeding, milking, making cheese and etc. You would need to bear with the animal smell. You can buy diary products from here.
The kids enjoyed seeing the place. Educational and there are cows, rabbits and goats. The presses of milking the cows, making cheese is educational.

This is located quite far from main city,,but we love driving in hills so it was a nice drive...on reaching there,,before the entrance only,,lush green farms spread far away was a visual treat...kids cheered as they saw lots of cows grazing,,in large numbers... Inside you can see the cows milking,,by machines,,then they also have rabbits and calves and big bulls... you can also enjoy glass of hot fresh milk,,or yummy yoghurt,,,they have other snacks too .. its anice place to visit..
The farm itself was great for the kids. The views are breathtaking. The drive to the farm was amazing! Never thought Sri Lanka would be part of heaven.

Ambewela farm is situated in a isolated area. This place must be a clean place more than now. Felt very sad about animals (Rabbits and cows). Nothing special to see.. :-( but Sri Lankan hill country view is marvellous....., no words that is a breathtaking view....!
Ambewela farm is the biggest milk farm in Sri Lnaka .Its location is very attractive .I and my Family enjoy very much in Ambewela .

Be aware that you have to walk inside on foot, so be ready for that with an umbrella if you travel in a rainy day or sun lotion and hats/ caps in a hot day. Basically you can see farm animals, cows, horses, rabbits, goats etc etc, raised for farm purposes and you have a good hill country view from there.. and some grass patches to walk and rest.. You can see the milking process and cheese making process if you wish to, buy their fresh products from their outlet.

This place is covered with good scenery of wide grass fields. the farm is a well equipped place as a genuine farm and it contains cows, goats and rabbits. For a person who hasn't been to a similar facility, this would be good experience. But if you have been to a farms before, doesn't think this would add much of difference. Also in both the occasions I went there the cheese manufacturing section was closed. I wood say a good one at the first time, and nothing much to pay a second visit.

Their New Zealand farms have an amazing view. The panorama is like you are in Switzerland or Scotland. The local shop needs drastic makeover & better staff & hygiene. The entry ticket is expensive seeing that not even a basic guide is provided.

it was a waste of time. shop did not have any milk products. No service is provided for the entrance fee paid. it was not a pleasant experience for me as the animals were caged and are was not clean. expectation was to see some animals in hanging out free.

Nice experience for children especially... Incredibly, the toilets were very clean, even though we visited during peak time with large crowds. Remember to try the different types of yoghurt, cheese etc available at the little dairy outlet.

The farm has a wide area for cattle and goat raising.  You'll be able to see how they maintain their productivity. I went to New Zealand farm during Sinhala New Year so there were a lot of local tourists. Nevertheless, the farm ables you to see the process of milk extraction and production.

visited Ambewela farm approximatly 17km from Nuwaraeliya town. Nice place to see Cows,goats & Rabbits raised for economic purposes.You could see the milking of cows on specific times.The cafetaria serves fresh milk , Yoghurt , snacks etc. Rs.100 for entrance not worth it, Rs.20 for children..You could see Rabbits raised for meat and Goat as well.

For starters... Tis a nice place, esp for people who have spent their entire lives in cities. For the farmers amongst you, it's ideas that u may or may not Wanna inculcate to your farms. It's got the cows in the wild grazing, a shed for calves, cows, rabbits, pregnant cows n of course the studs all separate. They have a mechanised method of milking the cows, which can be seen through a glass window. There are special timings for milking I witnessed the 12-1400 hrs batch on my way back from hortons plains. They have a canteen to snack and have a glass of nice hot milk if u wanna - the milk is pre sweetened!! They also have their own cheese factory - didn manage to see how they make the cheese though, but you can buy some from the canteen. It's nice if you have a kiddo... Kinda like a how it's made thingi. Oh and the most important thing - the animals are well kept and fed!! Foreigners entry 200/- for an adult.

We passed this Ambewela Farms on our way to Horten’s Plain from our hotel in Katukitula.  The travellers on the road that goes through the Farm onward to Horten’s Plain can feast their eyes on cattle grazing in the meadows. The whole farm area is very picturesque. Hills on both the sides are so green and lush. On our return journey, we decided to stop at Ambewela Farm as they have a little restaurant.  We had their delicious yogurt there.  We are not milk fans.  We were told one can actually go and do the farm tour but we were not interested nor more importantly had the time for it. Took the opportunity to just soak in the surroundings and take lots of photos. If you have the time, it is a good stop.

This is one of the best loaction I loved in and around Nuwara Eliya. Lies little away from Nuwara Eliya (about 15 km) at the high hills - the surrounding and secenary on the way is beautiful and one would love to just sit and enjoy the nature with fresh and coold air. I went there in April 2013 and managed to see inside the farm which was just great. They have a restaurant as well and one can buy the products of this farm. However, it was bad when I went there with my family last Decemebr - we found it closed for a month which was even not informed to me by my hotel as they were also not aware. Anyway - must visit place and one should go via Sita eliya and botanical garden to see this both place and return from other side to see the beauty of countrysides.
If this is not a heaven i would wonder how heaven is? Its a greeny farm where you can see cows free in the fields. One hour for photo opp is life memory which is not forgetten forever.
We visited this well maintained farm and enjoyed every second we stayed there. Recommend to any one who loves the nature and animals!,

Plan to drop in at this scenic and wonderful farm if you are making a trip to world's end/ Horton plains. Find out for times when opened for public viewing to make a tour in the farm. Last visited 2012

We visited Ambewala farms during our stay in Nuwara Eliya. We went as a group of 2 families with 4 kids and it was extremely fascinating experience for all 4 of them! They drive is very beautiful and picturesque - with hills covered in mist and dotted with cattle grazing around. Inside the farm, milking of the cows is something you'd like to watch, if you have kids along. There are also plenty of other farm animals like rabbits, billy goats for children to interact with. There is also a restaurant/ canteen inside where you can buy food but could work at being a little more clean and well maintained. On the whole, would definitely recommend this if you have small kids.
We traveled to Ambewela the drive was really nice and the road was good,The surrounding area is gorgeous

The nature surrounding the ambewela farm area is a very spectacular one, starting from the turn offat the  ambewela railway station to the farm it’s very pleasing nature view to the eye. The farm area is sometimes surrounded by mist and the weather can be very cold. Even though this was my second visit, my family and I really enjoyed the visit, the cows, goats, rabbits and specially the milking of the cows at 12.00-12.30pm which was an good experience that you don’t see every day. Farm has a shop available where you can by fresh milk, cheese, yoghurt …etc. , This is worth visiting

Especially educational for kids to appreciate the milk that they so much rave about (or hate so much). And for anything in the world don't miss out on the yoghurt you get there. It's creamy, smooth, well set and the best way to introduce it to your kids (if they do not have the habit already).

We traveled to Ambewela from Diyatalawa and the drive was really nice and the road was good. Closer to the farm the roads are narrow and winding so if your travelling with small kids , suggest you give them something to combat motion sickness. The area close to the farm is really beautiful with flowers and lots of green pastures . The farm itself is quite smelly but I suppose that goes with the territory  . It was really sad to see the cows and goats in sheds which were dark and dingy and the rabbits in cages where they could not move. The cheese factory was closed when we went and the restaurant's idea of milk shake was a scoop of ice cream in a glass of milk.   Toilets were terrible. The only consolation was that the kids enjoyed feeding the goats !
Unless you have a permit, you will not be able to visit the farm. However you get fresh milk and milk products for you to purchase at the entrance.
A good way to spend some of the day.. The surrounding area is gorgeous. Keep in mind that it is a farm so you will smell some nice odors. 100 rupees to enter

The first thing I noticed was the discriminatory sign saying adults 50rs, foreigners 100rs. I don't care that it's 50rs more, it's the nature that it's intented. The farm was a disappointment, the only good thing was the glass of fresh milk. Don't bother
I'm not much impressed due to the smell in the factory. It won't be a tourist attraction according to my experience. But overall, good experience for school students and children.

This is on the way to Horton Plains or Worlds End. The acres and acres of grazing fields are reminiscent of England or Denmark with weather to match equally. The farm serves very good edam cheese and excellent fresh milk. If you are a railroad buff, and if you are lucky you can spot a train or two chugging up a 1 foot to 45 foot gradient !!.

It is fairly long drive from Nuwara Eliya city centre to this farm and the roads are not great. If you intend to visit this place ensure that you club it with you visit to Worlds End as it is in the same route. I had gone with my kids so that they can experience the entire process from milking to packaging. The initial experience was quite nice however, it stops there and nothing further. The place is also not maintained well and there is no staff around who is keen to guide the visitors despite the fact that there is a entry charge to get into the diary. The surroundings is however lush green and huge areas for grazing, also the route is very scenic and will take any where between 30 to 40 minutes to reach from the city.
The rolling hills and grazing cows reminded me of New Zealand! The farm is so huge and the green fields seem to stretch forever.

The journey to Ambewala farm from N'eliya is approx. 17kms which would take about 30mints due to the roads not carpeted and lots of bends. You get to pass a beautiful lake and a dam which you will not feel like taking your eyes off from the view! If you go to nuwaraeliya, you should visit the ambewala farm to check out some giant animals! :-)
Its very valuable place to visit. We went to different sections. Cute little babies.... they are wonderful. We also had fresh milk from the farm.

Must visit place, any chance should not be missed.  Great experience to see the nature and farming.  Visitors are allowed to go inside the farm.   Cheese making centre is also avilable.  Don't miss to hvae a cup of hot farm fresh milk.

Its a long way to travel to get to Ambewela Farm from Nuwara Eliya. If you are going to worlds end make sure you make it in the same trip. You're visit will take about 1-2 hours based on the level of interest. There are particular times which you must be mindful of.eg:- time they milk cattle, feed them etc. But be ready for the foul smell inside the areas the animals are fed. You dont need any prior approval to enter this place. The entry ticket is Rs. 50 per person.

The road trip to Ambewela was a fabulous one! If you are lucky you can catch up on a Srilankan Railway train on the way. The entire farm is in a very scenic environment - very cool and refreshing. We were able to see large cows and milking plants. Of course, we made good purchases of local cheese also - which was too good!

When ever possible, I try to make a visit to Ambewela Farms. The scenic view and cool breeze is enough to attract anyone. I doesn't cost much either. Have good food, but the star attraction on food department is the Fresh Milk. They have also displayed all the products they manufacture in the food court. But my advice is to stick to the fresh stuff, since you can get the other stuff from any shop. Hmm.... well the farm animals are well maintained, little bit smelly but that goes with the territory I guess. Only bad think you can say is the ride, terrible road right up to the Railway crossing junction, beyond that the Farm has maintained the road well. So right upto that you have to stomach it and put up with the drive. Roads are narrow as well. On the way you can see the Ambewela Tank, with a small Dam constructed to hold water, to be supplied within the area.

Cool climes, Pastures more than green, Great place for kids and people who love to see the dairy industry indights to give it a go, dont miss to enjoy a hot glass of milk or munch a cube of fresh chesse
If you want to vist it, must u have entry piment  from head office in Colombo.
Very basic and nothing much to see. The facilities are not very clean either.
